label: A6B3C3D2_cI56_204_g_d_e_c-001
title: High Pressure Phase II (CH$_{3}$)(NH$_{3})$PbBr$_{3}$ Structure
comments:
CH$_{3}$NH$_{3}$PbBr$_{3}$ can be found in a variety of distorted \href{current_web_home_dir/AB3C_cP5_221_a_c_b-001}{perovskite ($E2_{1}$)} structures, depending upon the temperature and pressure (Abia, 2022; Liang, 2023): \begin{itemize} \item A low temperature \href{current_web_home_dir/A3BC6DE_oP48_62_cd_c_2c2d_c_a-001}{orthorhombic structure}, stable below 145K. \item This intermediate temperature \href{current_web_home_dir/A3B4C36D4E_oI192_74_ef_hi_2h8j_hi_c-001}{body-centered orthorhombic structure}, stable from 145-157K. \item An intermediate temperature \href{current_web_home_dir/A3B8C48D8E_tI272_140_ah_m_6m_m_c-001}{tetragonal structure}, stable from 156-229K. \item The room-temperature \href{current_web_home_dir/A3B12C144D12E_cP172_221_c_i_2k2n_i_b-001}{cubic perovskite-like structure}, stable above 229K. \item A \href{current_web_home_dir/A6B3C3D2_cI56_204_g_d_e_c-001}{cubic high-pressure Phase II structure}, stable from 0.9-1.8 GPa. \item An \href{current_web_home_dir/A3BC12DE_oP144_31_4a4b_4a_24b_4a_2b-001}{orthorhombic Phase III structure}, stable from 1.8-4.6 GPa. \item Another orthorhombic Phase IV structure was found by (Liang, 2023), but the atomic positions have yet to be calculated. \end{itemize} ~ \vspace{-.25in} 
 This structure was determined at 1.7GPa and 296K. 
 (Jaffe, 2016) do not report the positions of the hydrogen atoms.  We assume the species we label ``C'' and ``N'' are actually CH$_{3}$ and NH$_{3}$ radicals. 
 The (12d) site, which we label as carbon and is shown as a C-C dumbbell in the figures, is actually 41.667\% (5/12) CH$_{3}$ radicals, 41.667 NH$_{3}$ radicals, and 16.667 (1/12) vacancies. 
 The (12e) site, which we label as nitrogen and is shown as a nitrogen octahedron, is actually 25\% CH$_{3}$, 25\% NH$_{3}$, and 50\% vacancies. 
 The alternating (12d) and (12e) sites produce a double-perovskite, in contrast to the ``simple'' perovskites of the ambient pressure phases.
